children.name: to love sb especially in a sexual or romantic way
love
children.definition: /lʌv/  to have a strong feeling of liking someone, caring about them, and being sexually attracted to them:
examples: ▪ he stroked her hair and murmured, ‘i love you.’
▪ he was the only man she had ever loved.
love somebody very much
▪ we still love each other very much.

children.name: be in love
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈlʌv/  to love someone very much, so that you think about them all the time and want to be with them all the time:
examples: ▪ i think i’m in love!
be in love with
▪ how can you marry adam when you’re in love with someone else?
be madly in love/very much in lovevery strongly in love
▪ we were both seventeen and madly in love.

children.name: be crazy about
children.definition: /biː ˈkreɪzi əbaʊt/ informalto love someone very much, especially in a way that youcannotcontrol:
examples: ▪ jo’s crazy about you

children.name: fancy
children.definition: /ˈfænsi/  britishspokento be sexually attracted to someone, especially someone that youdo not know very well:
examples: mến
▪ all the girls fancy bob.
▪ i think stevie fancies you.

children.name: have a crush on
children.definition: /ˌhæv ə ˈkrʌʃ ɒn/  if someone, especially a young person, has a crush on someone they have an uncontrollable feeling of love for them, especially when there is no chance of having a relationship with them:
examples: ▪ it is quite normal for adolescents to have crushes on pop stars.
▪ the only reason i went to church every sunday was that i had a crush on the minister.

children.name: be besotted
children.definition: /biː bɪˈsɒtdǁ-ˈsɑː-/  to be so much in love with someone that you do not behave sensibly or think clearly:
examples: ▪ she was too besotted to see what he was really like.
be besotted with
▪ he was obviously besotted with julia.

children.name: be infatuated
children.definition: /biː ɪnˈfætʃueɪtd/  to have a strong and uncontrollable feeling of love for someone you do not know very well, which does not last for a long time:
examples: ▪ ever since she met rod at a party she’s been totally infatuated.
be infatuated with
▪ teenage girls sometimes become infatuated with their teachers.
infatuation/ɪnˌfætʃuˈeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
▪ i thought i was in love with darren, but it was just infatuation.

children.name: love
children.definition: /lʌv/  a feeling of love, either for someone that you are sexually attracted to, or for a member of your family:
examples: tình yêu
▪ all children need love, attention, and encouragement.
love for
▪ she was never able to express her love for henry.
unrequited loveromantic love that you feel for someone, but that they do not feel for you : tình yêu đơn phương
▪ she nourishes a secret, unrequited love for harry.

children.name: affection
children.definition: /əˈfekʃən/  a gentle feeling of love for afriendormemberof your family, which makes you want to be kind to them and show them that you love them:
examples: sự yêu mếm
▪ she never seemed to show us any affection.
▪ children who have been starved of affection
affection for
▪ alison and i had been at school together, and i felt great affection for her.

children.name: devotion
children.definition: /dɪˈvəʊʃən/  a strong feeling of loving and being loyal to someone, especially over a long period of time:
examples: ▪ she had given her husband years of devotion and support.
▪ mary expected complete devotion from her lovers.

children.name: passion
children.definition: /ˈpæʃən/  a strong and exciting feeling of love for someone you are extremely sexually attracted to:
examples: ▪ all the passion in their marriage has died.
▪ he loved her still, with just the same passion as he always had.

children.name: infatuation
children.definition: /ɪnˌfætʃuˈeɪʃən/  unreasonably strong feelings of love that you have for only a short time, especially for someone that you do not know very well:
examples: ▪ she hoped that his ridiculous infatuation would soon wear off.
infatuation with/for
▪ his infatuation with diane seemed to be growing.

children.name: affectionate
children.definition: /əˈfekʃənɪt, əˈfekʃənət/  someone who is affectionate shows that they are very fond of another person by the way they behave towards them, for example by holding or kissing them:
examples: trìu mến , tình cảm,
▪ she’s a very affectionate child.
▪ he gave me an affectionate hug and then lef

children.name: romantic
children.definition: /rəʊˈmæntɪk, rə-/  something that is romantic gives you a feeling of love for your boyfriend, girlfriend, husband, wife etc - use this aboutplaces, orthingspeople do or say:
examples: lãng mạn
▪ we went for a lovely romantic walk by the lake.
▪ paris is such a romantic city.
▪ i’ve always thought it would be so romantic to be serenaded.

children.name: loving
children.definition: /ˈlʌvɪŋ/  behaving in a way that shows that you love someone, especially a member of your family:
examples: ▪ her husband was loving and supportive throughout her long illness.
▪ she was a devoted wife and a very loving mother.

children.name: passionate
children.definition: /ˈpæʃənɪt, ˈpæʃənət/  involving strong feelings of sexual love:
examples: ▪ she longed to have a mad, passionate affair with him.
▪ as they got to know each other better, their love grew deeper and more passionate.

children.name: tender
children.definition: /ˈtendəʳ/  loving and gentle, especially because you are concerned about someone:
examples: ▪ when she spoke, her voice was full of tender concern.
▪ fleury saw an expression of tender devotion come over his father’s face.
tender loving care
▪ i was feeling rather fragile, and in need of tender loving care.
tenderness[uncountable noun]
▪ he looked after his wife with infinite care and tenderness.

children.name: lovesick
children.definition: /ˈlʌvˌsɪk/  spending all your time thinking about someone you love, especially someone who does not love you:
examples: ▪ he knew he was behaving like a lovesick teenager.

children.name: devoted
children.definition: /dɪˈvəʊtɪd, dɪˈvəʊtəd/  very loving and loyal towards someone:
examples: ▪ with the support of his devoted wife, he carried on writing until the age of 73.
▪ they remained devoted friends for many years.

children.name: doting
children.definition: /ˈdəʊtɪŋ/
examples: doting mother/grandparent/husband etc a mother, grandparent etc
that shows that they love someone, especially someone younger, by paying them a lot of attention:
▪ the doting grandmother smiled and chatted about how well the boy was doing at school.
▪ she managed to find a rich and doting husband for herself.

children.name: lovey-dovey/gooey
children.definition: /ˌlʌvi ˈdʌvi◂, ˈguːi/  informal expressing your love for someone in a way that other people think is silly:
examples: ▪ it is possible to love someone without going all gooey over them.
▪ we ended up sitting next to a lovey-dovey couple.

children.name: romance story
children.definition: romance/love story/rəʊˈmæns, ˈrəʊmæns, ˈlʌv ˌstɔːri/  a story about two people who are in love with each other:
examples: chuyện tình
▪ the book is very exciting, as well as being a wonderful love story.
▪ a well-known writer of popular romances

children.name: romantic
children.definition: /rəʊˈmæntɪk, rə-/  a romantic story or film is about people who are in love:
examples: ( chuyện tình ) lãng mạn
▪ a romantic comedy in which meg ryan plays a single mother looking for love

children.name: fall in love
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ɪn ˈlʌv/  tobeginto be in love with someone:
examples: ▪ i suddenly realized that i’d fallen in love.
fall in love with
▪ i think i fell in love with ralph the first time i met him.

children.name: fall/be head-over-heels (in love)
children.definition: /fɔːl, biː ˌhed əʊvəʳ ˌhiːlz (ɪn ˈlʌv)/  to suddenly start to love someone a lot:
examples: ▪ i met sam at college, and immediately fell head-over-heels in love with him.
▪ i was head-over-heels in love with someone who barely even noticed me.

children.name: fall for
children.definition: /ˈfɔːl fɔːʳ/  informal to start to love someone:
examples: ▪ she always seems to fall for the wrong type of man.
▪ i fell for dan almost immediately.

children.name: love at first sight
children.definition: /ˌlʌv ət fɜːʳst ˈsaɪt/  a situation in which you start to love someone the first time you see them:
examples: ▪ when i met tracy it was love at first sight.
▪ i don’t believe in love at first sight.

children.name: sweep somebody off their feet
children.definition: /ˌswiːp somebody ɒf ðeəʳ ˈfiːt/  if someone sweeps you off your feet, you start to love them very quickly, especially when you do not expect it to happen:
examples: ▪ then peter came into my life and swept me off my feet.
▪ she’s just waiting to be swept off her feet by a handsome stranger.

children.name: to like sb a lot and care about them
love
children.definition: /lʌv/  to love someone in your family, so that you care a lot about what happens to them, and you want them to be happy:
examples: ▪ i really believed that my parents didn’t love me.
▪ he loved his stepdaughter as if she were his own child.

children.name: close
children.definition: /kləʊs/  if people are close, they enjoy being together and they know and understand each other’s feelings and thoughts:
examples: ▪ my sister and i used to argue a lot, but now we’re very close.
▪ we have always been a close family.
close to
▪ i’m still very close to my parents.

children.name: adore
children.definition: /əˈdɔːʳ/  to love someone very much and feel proud of them:
examples: ▪ branwell bronte adored his sister anne.
▪ she adores her grandchildren and is always buying them presents.

children.name: be fond of
children.definition: /biː ˈfɒnd ɒvǁ-ˈfɑːnd-/  to like someone very much, especially after spending a long time with them and getting to know them:
examples: ▪ i’m very fond of my sister’s children.
▪ all teachers have children that they are particularly fond of.
▪ we were all very fond of mr edwards.

children.name: care
children.definition: /keəʳ/  to feel love and concern for someone:
examples: ▪ she thinks we’re interfering but we’re only doing it because we care.
▪ buy her some flowers to show her you really care.
care about
▪ i’m very lucky to have a husband, family and friends who care about me.
▪ of course i care about kirsty - that’s why i want to help her.

children.name: worship
children.definition: /ˈwɜːʳʃɪp/  to love and admire someone very much:
examples: ▪ he worshipped his elder brother.
worship the ground somebody walks on
love someone very much, even if they behave badly
▪ in susie’s eyes he can do no wrong - she worships the ground he walks on.

children.name: be devoted to
children.definition: /biː dɪˈvəʊtd tuː/  to love someone very much and be very loyal to them or spend all your time with them:
examples: ▪ he is a good man, devoted to his wife and children.

children.name: dote on
children.definition: /ˈdəʊt ɒn/  to love someone, especially someone younger than you, very much and show this by your actions:
examples: ▪ he’d do anything for his children - he really dotes on them.
▪ she obviously dotes on her grandson.
▪ you should visit your aunt more often, you know how she dotes on you all.

children.name: think the world of
children.definition: /ˌθɪŋk ðə ˈwɜːʳld ɒv/  to love and respect someone so much that they are very important in your life:
examples: ▪ we all thought the world of isaac and were devastated when he died.
▪ he thinks the world of his uncle.

children.name: unloved
children.definition: /ˌʌnˈlʌvd◂/  not loved by someone or anyone:
examples: ▪ as a child i felt very unloved.
▪ he was the unloved son of an unhappy marriage.
